questions.text: 8 year old female child following URTI developed maculopapular rash on the jaw spreading onto the trunk which cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation and tender postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Option 1
  • Kawasaki disease (KD), also known as Kawasaki syndrome, is an acute febrile illness of unknown cause that primarily affects children younger than 5 years of age. Clinical signs include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, irritation and redness of the whites of the eyes, swollen lymph glands in the neck, and irritation and inflammation of the mouth, lips, and throat.
  • Causes: No one knows what causes Kawasaki disease, but scientists don't believe the disease is contagious from person to person. A number of theories link the disease to bacteria, viruses or other environmental factors, but none has been proved. Certain genes may increase your child's susceptibility to Kawasaki disease.
Option 2

Erythema infectiosum:

  • Caused by Parvovirus B19
  • Children (fifth disease) - Slapped cheek rashes
  • Adults - Polyarthropathy
Option 3

1. Points in favor of Rubella are:

  • Maculopapular rash on the face spreading onto the trunk.
  • Rash is cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation.
  • Tender post-auricular and sub-occipital lymphadenopathy.

2. Rubella is a milder and more subtle disease than measles.

3. Postnatal rubella:

  • Virus excreted in oropharyngeal secretions and infection is acquired by inhalation.
  • Virus multiplies locally in upper respiratory tract & cervical lymph nodes ? viraemia, dissemination throughout the body.
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks, fine pink macules first appearing on the face and then spreading to involve trunk and limbs.
  • Enlargement of postauricular, suboccipital, posterior cervical lymph nodes.
  • Recovery within 3-4 days of appearance of rash.
  • Complications: Polyarthritis (adult women, thrombocytopenic purpura, encephalopathy, panencephalitis

4. Congenital rubella:

  • Virus can cross the placental barrier and infect the fetus.
  • Congenital anomalies/death of the fetus.
  • Congenital defects: deafness, cataract, glaucoma, microphthalmia, retinopathy, congenital heart disease (patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary artery stenosis), microcephaly, mental retardation, thrombocytopenic purpura, hepatosplenomegaly.
Option 4
  • MEASLES (RUBEOLA) VIRUS: Maculopapular dusky red rashes appear after four days of fever (i.e. at 14th day of infection).

questions.text: According to FIGO staging, stage 3 cervical carcinoma involves:
questions.explanation:
Stage Description
I Confined to cervix
IA Microinvasive (diagnosed only by microscopy)
IA1 Stromal invasion not >3 mm deep
IA2 Stromal invasion 3-5 mm deep
IB Invasive carcinoma with measured deepest invasion ≥5 mm (greater than stage IA), lesion limited to the cervix uteri
IB1 Clinically visible lesion >5mm in depth and <2 cm in greatest dimension
IB2 Clinically visible lesion ≥2cm and <4 cm in greatest dimension

IB3

 Invasive carcinoma ≥4cm in greatest dimension
II The carcinoma invades beyond the uterus, but has not extended onto the lower third of the vagina or to the pelvic wall
IIA Involvement limited to the upper 2/3rd of the vagina without parametrial involvement
IIA1 Invasive carcinoma <4 cm in greatest dimension
IIA2

Invasive carcinoma ≥4 cm in greatest dimension
IIB With parametrial involvement but not upto the pelvic wall
III

Extends to pelvic wall, and/or involves lower 1/3rd of vagina and/or causes hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney,involves pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes
IIIA Involves lower 1/3rd vagina but not extension into pelvic side wall
IIB Extension into pelvic side wall and/or hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney

IIIC

Involvement of pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes, irrespective of tumor size and extent (with r and p notations)

  • IIIC1 -Pelvic lymph node metastasis only
  • IIIC2 -Paraaortic lymph node metastasis

IV

 Carcinoma has extended beyond true pelvis or has involved (biopsy proven) the mucosa of the bladder or rectum
IVA Spread of the growth to adjacent organs (bladder or rectum)
IVB Distant metastases

questions.correct_answer: A. Leave IUD in-situ, continue pregnancy
questions.explanation:
IUCD Type Uses Contraindications
Copper IUCD - Highly effective long-term contraception. - Known or suspected pregnancy.
  - Provides contraception for up to 10 years. - Active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  - No hormonal side effects. - Current or recent pelvic infection.
  - Emergency contraception within 5 days of unprotected sex. - Abnormal uterine anatomy (e.g., distorted cavity).
  - Suitable for women who cannot use hormonal methods. - Current or recent cervical or uterine cancer.
  - Immediate return to fertility after removal. - Severe liver disease or liver tumors.
Levonorgestrel-releasing IUCD (LNG-IUCD) - Highly effective long-term contraception. - Known or suspected pregnancy.
(Also known as hormonal IUD) - Provides contraception for 3 to 7 years, depending on the type. - Active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  - Reduces menstrual bleeding and cramps. - Current or recent pelvic infection.
  - Suitable for women with heavy or painful periods. - Abnormal uterine anatomy (e.g., distorted cavity).
  - May be used as part of medical management of heavy periods. - Current or recent cervical or uterine cancer.
  - Effective emergency contraception within 5 days of unprotected sex. - Known or suspected breast cancer.
  - Immediate return to fertility after removal. - Severe liver disease or liver tumors.
Progestin-only IUCD - Highly effective long-term contraception. - Known or suspected pregnancy.
  - Provides contraception for up to 3 years. - Active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  - Suitable for women who cannot use estrogen-containing methods. - Current or recent pelvic infection.
  - May be used while breastfeeding. - Abnormal uterine anatomy (e.g., distorted cavity).
  - Immediate return to fertility after removal. - Current or recent cervical or uterine cancer.
    - Known or suspected breast cancer.
    - Severe liver disease or liver tumors.

questions.text: What is the correct preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality?

options.label: A
options.text: RCT > Retrospective cohort > Prospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional

options.label: B
options.text: RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional

options.label: C
options.text: RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study> Case-control

options.label: D
options.text: RCT > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study > Cross-sectional > Case-control

questions.correct_answer: B. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Option B. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
  • ↳ Option B. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
  • ↳ Explanation:
  • ↳ Explanation:
  • ↳ Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) - RCTs are considered the gold standard for establishing causality in epidemiological research. They involve randomization, which minimizes bias, and the controlled experimental design allows for strong causal inferences. Prospective Cohort Study - Prospective cohort studies follow a group of individuals over time to assess their exposure and outcomes. They are particularly useful for studying causal relationships because they can establish temporal relationships between exposure and outcome. Retrospective Cohort Study - Retrospective cohort studies also provide valuable data but may be subject to recall bias, making them slightly less robust for establishing causality than prospective cohort studies. Case-Control Study - Case-control studies are observational and compare individuals with a particular outcome (cases) to those without it (controls) to determine exposure differences. While they are useful for generating hypotheses, they are less strong for establishing causality due to issues like recall bias. Cross-Sectional Study - Cross-sectional studies provide a snapshot of a population at a single point in time. They are primarily descriptive and are generally weaker in establishing causality, as they do not capture temporal relationships between exposure and outcome.

While they are useful for generating hypotheses, they are less strong for establishing causality due to issues like recall bias.

Term Definition
Net reproduction rate Total No. of girl children born to a female, taking into account their mortality.
Gross reproduction rate Total no. of girl children born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span (15-44 or 49 years), assuming no mortality
Total marital fertility rate Total no. of children that would be born to a married woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span
